title.narrative: Bridging the Gaps 2 - PWUD project Kenya

description.narrative: Bridging the Gaps works with a Theory of Change approach. A Theory of Change is a description of a list of events that is expected to lead to a particular desired outcome. It is a visualization how change is believed to happen. In 2016, representatives of the PWUD community developed a specified Theory of Change that consists of short-,medium, and long term outcomes. The Theory of Change describes how we plan to realize stronger engagement of PWUD in decision-making processes and research; a more positive and enabling legal, political and economic environment for PWUD; and more equal access to health services, especially harm reduction, TB and Hep. C services and HIV and STI services. Through innovation and by building on previous work, we will strengthen civil society organisations’ ability to: 1. We facilitate community development - Building capacity of PWUD on proposal writing and providing linkages to institutions for start-up capital. - Organizing family forums, enrolling and mentoring parents in the methadone programme. - Providing prevention for vulnerable youth through training and mentoring their parents. - Disseminating IEC harm reduction materials targeting women who use drugs, people staying at drug dens and in prison. - Capacity strengthening in the form of policy development, governance, representation in Global Fund process advocacy activities, including emphasis on gender. - Establishing a women’s network within KeNPUD. 2. We advocate for the continuously strengthening of services and upholding human rights - Promoting drug policy and a legal framework for scaling up financial sustainability of harm reduction services to PWUD. - Communicating and engaging in advocacy with politicians, the judiciary, law enforcement and media to gain more support of harm reduction work. 3. We deliver inclusive, rights-based and gender sensitive services - Providing pharmaceutical drugs (antibiotics, anti-malaria, analgesia, sedatives, antidepressants) and non-pharmaceutical drugs (screening kits, HIV rapid test kits, STI test kits, speculum, stand lamp, forceps, sterile gauze). - Providing comprehensive health care services to PWUD at the DIC, in prison and at the drug dens. Providing nutrition support and social services. - Supporting outreach workers in meeting their own basic health and safety needs.

Kenya (population 45 million) is an East-African country on the Indian Ocean that borders Somalia, Tanzania, Uganda, South-Sudan and Ethiopia. Well known for its wildlife parks and safaris, it also has a history of terrorist attacks. Over the years, due to its strategic location, Kenya has become an important transit hub for heroin from South-East Asia. HIV has seriously affected the general population as well as key populations such as People Who Inject Drug (PWID), whose HIV prevalence is estimated to be over 18%. With the introduction of needle and syringe programs, harm reduction services first became available in 2011, followed by methadone treatment in 2014. Mainline started supporting local NGOs that work with drug users in 2012 in offering outreach services, Needles and Syringe Programmes (NSP), nutritional support, advocacy for health and human rights. Mainline started working in Kenya during the first Bridging the Gaps program in 2012. MEWA is the main implementing partner under BtG2 in Kenya.

sector.narrative: Service delivery to PWID to prevent HIV infections

title.narrative: 5 Human Rights violation cases acted on

description.narrative: Human rights violation cases acted on is the number of violations documented and in the process of being acted on, instead of responded to, meaning that the cases are taken further than documentation, for example reporting, providing psychosocial and or paralegal or legal support.

title.narrative: 5 # human rights violation cases acted on

description.narrative: 5 # human rights violation cases acted on. This is the number of violations documented and in the process of being acted on, instead of ‘responded to’, meaning that the cases are taken further than documentation, for example reporting, providing psychosocial and or paralegal or legal support.

comment.narrative: The cases were documented and clients were referred to psychosocial and paralegal or legal support
the cases were acted upon and the clients linked to care and (para) legal services (Male 58 Female 14

title.narrative: 3 Law enforcement staff trained on human rights

description.narrative: Law enforcement staff trained on human rights is measured by the number of law enforcement staff trained on human rights.

title.narrative: 3 # law enforcement staff trained on human rights

description.narrative: 3 # law enforcement staff trained on human rights

comment.narrative: 120 (80M:40F). Sensitazation on Harm reduction services and access to social justice to police enforcers in 3 counties, Mombasa,Kilifi and Lamu.

title.narrative: 4 Participation of partner organization in or organization of local national regional or global stakeholder meetings

description.narrative: Participation of partner organization in or organization of local national regional or global stakeholder meetings is measured by the number of partner organisations that participate in meetings. Meetings are defined as advocacy meetings with local national regional or global stakeholders.

title.narrative: 4 # partner organisations that participated in or organized local/national/regional/global stakeholder meetings

description.narrative: 4 # partner organisations that participated in or organized local/national/regional/global stakeholder meetings is measured by the number of partner organisations. Meetings are advocacy meetings with local/national/regional/global stakeholders.

comment.narrative: 4 meetings on local level (different fora of community police, and 2 on National level (Ministry of Interior Security and Ministry of Health)
Local meeting in the community the main aim to discuss the rise of young youth gang and rising of violence.

title.narrative: 1 Service provision to Key Population Members

description.narrative: Service provision to key population members measures the number of services used by key population members. This is done through 6 indicators that respectively measure the number of testing services, treatment services, PWUD specific medical harm reduction services, other health services meaning condom distribution, social services and legal support services used by key population members.

title.narrative: 1C # of KP members using PWUD specific medical harm reduction services

description.narrative: 1C # of KP members using PWUD specific medical harm reduction services (disaggregated by age) including needle exchange, OST, OD prevention, PWUD specific counselling

comment.narrative: Bridging the Gaps uses two age groups since 2017 reporting onwards: 24 and under, and 25 and above, as agreed with MOFA. For the sex work project, the youngest age group will be 18-24 years. Mainline and partners have additional dimensions which are used to monitor reach of services: Male, female and other.

Bridging the Gaps uses two age groups since 2017 reporting onwards: 24 and under, and 25 and above, as agreed with MOFA. For the sex work project, the youngest age group will be 18-24 years. Our partner in Kenya has reached more than double the target number set. This is due to efficient and improved outreach strategy and work. Also, due to gender specific project implemented since 2018, they were able to reach more women compared to previous years

Also, due to gender specific project implemented in 2018, they were able to reach more women compared to previous years

description.narrative: Trained service providers is measured through 2 indicators. The first measures the number of service providers trained. Service providers provide social services, including psychosocial support, health education and promotion, online counselling, or health NGO or public sector services. The counselling part of VCT services is excluded. They are individuals within local partner organisations within BtG that provide services, as well as from indirect service providers that receive training from BtG local partners for instance other NGO-run clinics, private clinics, state-run services, etc. The second measures the number of legal service providers trained including paralegal services

2A # of service providers trained. This is the number of individual service providers meaning staff members, trained by alliance partner and/or by a country partner. Total # is the number of people trained by alliance partner and number of people trained by partners. Service providers provide social (including psychosocial support, health education and promotion, online counselling, NOT the counselling part of VCT services), or health(NGO or public sector) services. They are individuals within local partner organisations within BtG that provide services, as well as from indirect service providers that receive training from BtG local partners (e.g. other NGO-run clinics, private clinics, state-run services, etc).

comment.narrative: 5 (1M:4F): MEWA clinical team trained on: new update guidelines on clinical services i.e STI, HTS, HEP B and C,PrEP linkages and follow up.
Service providing staff members were training on national new update gidlines on clinical services i.e STI, HTS, HEP B and C, linkages and follow up

description.narrative: 2B # legal service providers trained including paralegal services

comment.narrative: 12 (7M:5F). An intensive one month paralegal training supported by Global Fund
Refresher training on paralegal services.
